awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Visual Architectures: Engaging Crowds in Design and Discovery for Custom Reconfigurable Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Custom reconfigurable computing platforms offer low power, high performance, high efficiency, and increased redundancy tailored to the needs of a specific application domain. The ability to successfully create these highly customized domain-specific architectures offers tremendous advantages, including orders of magnitude power savings, longer battery lives, smaller, faster, more robust devices, and a shorter time to market. However, making extreme customization an integral part of the design process requires design to be significantly simpler to create novel, out of the box architectures that directly address the requirements of a specific domain. This challenge can be divided into three specific areas: (1) discover fast, efficient algorithms that allow for rapid design space exploration; (2) increase participation and widen the community by promoting computational thinking among non-scientists and non-engineers; and (3) educate the next generation of custom chip designers through innovative visual frameworks. Effective multiplayer and cooperative games will be developed in this project that allow teams of players to collaboratively solve mapping and design problems of much larger scope and complexity. In this respect the project also involves members if underrepresented groups in a major way. 

This research is centered around the idea of developing Visual Architectures to address the challenges outlined above. More specifically, the project involves: (a) creating a highly visual, game-like design environment, thus making complex architecture and mapping problems accessible leading to greater engagement and significantly increasing participation; (b) analyze the vast amounts of data generated through the widening player community to discover better, more efficient automated algorithms; (c) employ the interactive platforms thus created to educate the next generation of chip designers and build their skills and intuitions.

por.por_cntn:
The major goals of this research are: (i) to create and deploy a highly visual game-like architecture design environment and engage a broader community of players in experimenting with architecture design, (ii)  to design and deploy a next-generation visual mapping environment for constrained architectures, (iii) to develop and deploy effective multiplayer and cooperative games that allows teams of players to work collaboratively to solve mapping and design challenges of much larger scope and complexity, (iv) to analyze vast amounts of data generated through the widening player community to discover better and more efficient strategies, and (v) to educate the next generation of chip designers through innovative visual frameworks.

We have developed an online visual interactive design framework for constrained and complex mapping problems. We have developed a single player version where players all over the world can compete, and community and multiplayer versions for community and collaborative efforts. When the problem gets very challenging for a single player to solve, we provide a community version of the game where players can build upon others' solutions. We have also developed a multiplayer game where players from all over the world can collaborate, chat, exchange their ideas / strategies to solve such complex problems. We have also developed an interactive design exploration framework to study and explore low-energy fault-tolerant reconfigurable designs. We have made our frameworks available online free to a broader audience. These can be used to promote computational thinking among people without science and engineering background. We have demonstrated our design frameworks at the IEEE / ACM Design Automation Conference SIGDA University Demo sessions. We have also presented our research at TexasWISE and IEEE Circuits and Systems Society Dallas Chapter.  We have also conducted a tutorial on game-driven electronic design automation in an international conference on women researchers in electronics and computing. We have conducted world wide online gaming competitions using our design environments. We have used our frameworks to teach fundamentals of integrated circuit design in a fun and interactive way in electrical engineering courses. We have conducted several outreach events for elementary, middle, and high school students through STEM@thePark, I-STEM, Navy JROTC, Girl Powered, Digi Girlz, Mindbender Academy, Girl Power Huddle programs. We have presented our research to Texas Academy of Science and Mathematics and Honors College students. We have conducted gaming events for the Society of Women Engineers at UNT. This research has given great educational opportunities to a large number of undergraduate and graduate students including female students and students from underrepresented groups.
